text.p: Manila overnight money was firm at an average of 9.9375 percent on Tuesday as most banks were able to square their positions immediately, traders said.
Done rates moved from 10.15625 to 9.9375 percent, with 31 lenders and 18 borrowers.
"Banks quickly lent to the Central Bank in case the Central Bank again closes its overnight borrowing facility," a dealer said.
Traders further noted that the Central Bank kept its overnight borrowing rate at 9.9 percent, which placed a floor on rates.

In the secondary market, the lowering of the Central Bank's one-year rate to 10.3 from 10.4 percent on its special series T-bill spurred banks to buy more bills. Its action was to align with the results of Monday's T-bill sales.
Traders said banks decided to purchase bills before rates slide further.
A Reuter poll of eight financial insitutions showed bid rates of 9.45 to 9.60 percent on three-month bills, 9.80 to 10.05 on six months, and 10.375 to 10.525 on the one-year bills.
